answers.answer: hi! i had a c-sec in july. the spinal was fine. i know some people have trouble with it, but mine went in easily- and i'm terrified of needles. i felt the tiny pinch of the first needle that numbs- after that just slight pressure. you sit on the table facing a nurse who braces you to make sure you don't move.during the surgery i felt pressure. honestly, i didn't know when they had started cutting. it felt like they were pressing gently on my tummy- i thought they were feeling around for the baby, turns out i had already been cut. i did have some problems during the procedure with a very intense chest pain, but the anesthesiologist said it was heart burn and common, and he quickly gave me something to calm me when i started to panic. oh yea- i also felt a lot of pressure when she was actually delivered because someone was practically jumping on my chest to push her out. but that didn't hurt- just caught me by surprise.my recovery was a bit different than typical since i had to be on magnesium sulfate for 24 hrs, and to be closely monitored. they checked the protein levels in my urine every hour during the night, and monitored my bp, but that was because of preeclampsia. they did bring me my baby shortly after i went to recovery, and put her to my breast. i suspect that as long as you and baby are healthy, you'll see her almost immediately after she's checked in the nursery and you're out of the or.they'll probably have you try to walk within 24 hours. you'll also go to the bathroom around then, as soon as your catheter is removed. they wanted a nurse with me the first 2 times i went. they measured how much i peed. it was weird, cause it was very hard for me to pee at first, it too like 15 minutes, and the poor nurse stood patiently and kindly waited for me. she even ran the faucet to help me go!my c-sec was monday, and i was released friday. as long as your baby is healthy, she'll go home with you.my recovery was tough too, although i imagine it's about the same for everyone. we actually moved downstairs for a few weeks since i was only allowed to climb stairs once/day. it was worth it though! it's still too fresh in my mind to consider doing it again, but i am sure i will at some point in time. good luck and enjoy your little miracle!

That worries me about stairs, I have a flight to go up and down every day.I do remember when they removed my cath they said I could go to the bathroom but I never had them measure my pee. Weird. LOLThe doctor told me I would be on morphine for 24 hours afterwards or something. With my last one I had a epidural and I can't remember what drugs they had me on for pain afterwards.

If you have a spinal, they put a form of long acting morphine in the spinal, so it helps with the pain for 24 hours.  If you have more pain than you can handle, there are usually other meds they can give you, too.You'll be in for 3 or 4 days, depending on how you do and whether you have complications or not.  You'll usually get up either later that day, or the next morning.  They'll usually take out the IV and the catheter in 24 hours.  Most times, the baby never leaves your side but this can vary by hospital policy.

Never had one, but wanted to wish you good luck!  My sis had 3 of them and each one was easier for her to recover from.  I got to hold mine after, but had vaginal deliveries.  I never fleta thing after my epidurals though,  I can imagine that yours will be even stronger.  Just think, not long now till you have your baby to cuddle in your arms.

the long acting morphine was great!! after that, make sure you stay on top of taking you r pain meds. i didn't know at first that you have to ask for them- they don't just give it to you. i alternated the percocet and motrin, about 3 hrs apart.you will have to minimize stair climbing, so plan your trips. don't just run upstairs for a brush or anything. downstairs worked for us cause we were up all night at first. since i wasn't breastfeeding, i had to wash bottles, etc... and would've had to go up and down a lot during the night. plus, in the summer, it was hot upstairs
Did you throw up from the morphine? Someone told me that after it wears off I will be throwing up for atleast 24 hours, I really don't like the thought of that.

nope. i didn't really feel any side effects other than dopey. i had itching and general cr@ppiness, but i was told that was from the magnesium sulfate. i liked the morphine and missed it when it wore off :)

No, not from the Duramorph (the long acting one in the spinal).  Morphine that is given IV can make some people nauseated, but most people tolerated it just fine.You may vomit simply from having surgery, though.  They'll have meds for nausea if you need them.

Yeah I think that's what the doc told me, they put it in through the spinal. I tried to explain this drug was probably a different morphine but they insisted I would probably still get sick. It makes me feel better to know I probably won't. Maybe I should take a couple gravol before I go in for surgery?
In about 17 hours my baby will be here. EEK!

don't take anything before going in to surgery. i wasn't allowed to eat or drink anything. i wasn't allowed to take my heartburn medication which left me miserable while i waited. they didn't even let me have ice chips :(
Right, don't take anything prior to surgery.  They'll give you meds if you need them.

question: I have had a previous c section before but it was emergency, it was also nearly 5 years ago so I remember very little, everything is such a blur now other then remembering the terrible recovery I had.The doctor informed me I will be having a spinal block, never had one before. Anyone have one? What does it feel like? Will I feel anything during surgery? What should I expect recovery wise? How long before they will allow me to try and walk? Go to the bathroom? How long do they keep someone in the hospital after c section? Will they bring my baby to me right away or will I have to wait? With my daughter it was nearly 12 hours before I got to hold her. :(I'm actually really freaked out over this. :(Thanx.
title: Having my baby in less then 48 hours
